awd_titl_txt: Symposium on Scientific and Engineering Tools to Address Grounwater Depletion
awd_abstract_narration:
1643241 
Pinder, George F.

This grant is to help support a symposium on scientific and engineering tools to address groundwater depletion. The symposium will be held on October 11, 2016, in Washington DC. While various scientific and engineering tools for the analysis and management of groundwater exist, they are dispersed across a number of disciplines in universities, and additionally experts on this topic are found in many government agencies. The proposed symposium will bring together an interdisciplinary group of distinguished scientists and engineers that crosses these disciplinary and administrative boundaries. 

The benefits will be 1. communication of the state of knowledge between these experts and 2. identification of the tools needed to address groundwater depletion and 3. an improved strategy to deal with this critical problem. As stated in the list of grand challenges of the NAE, "...about one out of every six people living today do not have adequate access to water and more than double that number lack basic sanitation, for which water is needed...." Of the various sources of fresh water, groundwater makes up thirty percent. In some areas of the US it is a mined resource and not easily replenished. The symposium is dedicated to the effective evaluation, monitoring and management of this resource. This symposium has the potential to make a major impact on the quality of life of an enormous number of people. The symposium is intended to stimulate a greater awareness and continuing discussion of the critical challenge of water resources and provide scientific fundamentals to be drawn upon for the development of national policies to more effectively address the challenge.

por.por_cntn:
The Symposium on Scientific and Engineering Tools to Address Groundwater Depletion brought together 58 scientists from government, academia, and industry to discuss the groundwater depletion. The symposium included 8 presentations on topics related to modeling, monitoring, and understanding groundwater resources. Discussions were facilitated between a diverse group of attendees with the goal of raising awareness of issues concerning groundwater resources that would be continued after the one day meeting and influence decisions made with regards to future research, funding, and policies.

The keynote was given by Stavros Papadopulos from S.S. Papadopulos & Associates Inc. on the safe yield and sustainable development of aquifers. Dr. Papadopulos talked extensively on whether pumping an aquifer continuously without depletion is sustainable and that we must always consider the impact on nearby wells, streams, and wetlands when talking about sustainable extraction of water.

Six panel talks were given on monitoring and developing water resources. Bridget Scanlon from the University of Texas at Austin gave the first talk, 'Towards a more sustainable management of groundwater resources'. She talked about the need to compare global water models to GRACE data to understand the trends in water availability and how the current global models behave. She compared multiple models to long term trends observed by GRACE. Dr. Scanlon found that the greatest difference between models and GRACE data occurred in large, humid, and heavily irrigated basins. She also found that models underestimate both increases and decreases in total water in basins.

The second talk was given by Leonard Konikow from the USGS titled 'Assessment and impacts of long-term groundwater depletion'. Dr. Konikow's talk focused on the impacts of groundwater depletion such as vegetation loss and reduced river flow. Depletion was measured through volume losses in an aquifer and through water level drops. Both are useful because they are able to characterize different impacts to depletion.  Dr. Konikow concluded that there are two options for dealing with depletion, we can either do nothing and wait for the system to self-limit itself, or we can actively manage reservoirs by decreasing demand and/or increasing recharge and supply.

The third talk was given by James Butler of the Kansas Geological Survey and the University of Kansas titled 'Assessing the sustainability of aquifers supporting irrigated agriculture'. Dr. Butler focused on the high planes aquifer which supplies 90% of the water in Kansas and is critical to food production in the state. He modeled the aquifer using a data based approach on a resolution of several hundred km2 from water level change in around 1,400 wells. His work shows that reducing pumping in Kansas by between 15-29% will stabilize water losses within the aquifer. He did not think it is possible to recharge the aquifer.

The fourth talk was given by Jay Famiglietti from the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory titled 'Groundwater depletion and freshwater availability as viewed from space'. His talk focused on GRACE, the Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment. Dr. Famiglietti highlighted several of the interesting results that the GRACE mission has identified. These results include: the water loss in California (15 km3 exceeding the water used by its population (10 km3); the upper U.S. is getting wetter and the lower U.S. is getting drier; the primary areas of food production in the U.S. are being depleted, putting food security at risk; and across the world water depletion may lead to conflicts over water rights.

The fifth talk was given by Michelle Sneed from the USGS titled 'Land subsidence: The lowdown on the drawdown’. Dr. Sneed focused on land subsidence as caused by groundwater depletion and showed some startling images of subsidence in California where the ground is sinking by as much as 1ft per year. The cause of subsidence in CA is the rearranging of clay particles when the water level drops and this process is irreversible.

The sixth talk was given by Gretchen Miller from Texas A&M University titled 'Role of earth systems modeling in sustainable groundwater management'. Dr. Miller focused on the need to consider ecological sustainability when considering groundwater management. This includes the role that rooted plants play in the health of surrounding plants. She stressed how important modeling feedbacks between the groundwater system and the ecological system is in understanding the impacts of groundwater depletion. Specifically, groundwater dependent ecosystems take up around 146 MGD in Texas.

The final talk was given by William Alley from the National Groundwater Association titled 'The many faces of groundwater depletion'. Dr. Alley focused on determining how stressed an aquifer is by combining data and models over multiple scales both spatially and temporally. He concluded that in order to mitigate stresses we need to include various climate scenarios and consider the impacts of groundwater depletion with hydrologic timescales in mind.

A video of the presentations  can be found at https://blog.uvm.edu/webwizrd-nae/presentations/ .
